description: Bermondsey owes much of its importance to the proximity of London's docks, making Bermondsey into 'London's Larder', where food was processed and stored. Come on this tour with a Bermondsey local and discover the history of the area and learn about the areas more recent transformation into the artistic and commercial hub we see today.

events.name: Bermondsey: The Story of London’s Larder

factsheet.heading: Larder of London
paragraphs: Bermondsey was called the larder of London because it was a major centre for the processing and distribution of food in the 18th and 19th centuries. Being located on the River Thames it was the ideal place for importing and exporting food, with a number of docks, warehouses, and factories, which were used to store and process food.

A number of major food processing companies, including Crosse & Blackwell, Huntley & Palmers, and Harveys of Bristol had factories in Bermondsey. These companies produced a wide variety of food products, including canned food, biscuits, and sauces.

factsheet.heading: Golden Key Academy
paragraphs: This tour is led by a participant of Open City’s Golden Key Academy – a course training up insightful and engaging guides dedicated to explaining London and bringing its many stories to life. It is part of a wider collection of tour events created by Golden Key Academy guides for the Open House Festival celebrating their conclusion of the eight month course.
Further information on the Golden Key Academy can be found here https://open-city.org.uk/golden-key-academy

name: Bermondsey: The story of London's Larder
